Not only because it is a mortal extension of Eldrazor's Arena of Death, but also because by sacrificing his life he could save thousands of others.

short_description.last_approved_text: Those who yearn to fight in the name of honour must seek out Eldrazor.

technologies.short_description: Those who yearn to fight in the name of honour must seek out Eldrazor.

long_description.last_approved_text: The Lord of Destruction has a complicated past and an even more complicated relationship with his children. Legend tells that he had over a hundred offspring, known as the Ellinilli, and together they brought untold destruction to the Elves. Isha pleaded with the other gods to stop the path of destruction, but her pleas fell on deaf ears - deaf except for Loec, who saw an opportunity to use his fabled wit against Ellinill. Convincing him that his children were plotting a coup, Ellinill devoured them all.

technologies.long_description: The Lord of Destruction has a complicated past and an even more complicated relationship with his children. Legend tells that he had over a hundred offspring, known as the Ellinilli, and together they brought untold destruction to the Elves. Isha pleaded with the other gods to stop the path of destruction, but her pleas fell on deaf ears - deaf except for Loec, who saw an opportunity to use his fabled wit against Ellinill. Convincing him that his children were plotting a coup, Ellinill devoured them all.

short_description.last_approved_text: For those that crave the destruction of their enemies, Ellinill is always happy to help.

technologies.short_description: For those that crave the destruction of their enemies, Ellinill is always happy to help.

long_description.last_approved_text: Also known as the Pale Queen, Ereth Khial is the Supreme Goddess of the Underworld. Unhappy with her place in the Elven Pantheon, she spent most of her time plotting ways to topple Asuryan from his throne. However, she has bigger things to worry about now, namely Slaanesh. The army of Elven souls she was attempting to build is somewhat diminished of late, as the Dark Prince claims many of the choicest specimens for himself.

technologies.long_description: Also known as the Pale Queen, Ereth Khial is the Supreme Goddess of the Underworld. Unhappy with her place in the Elven Pantheon, she spent most of her time plotting ways to topple Asuryan from his throne. However, she has bigger things to worry about now, namely Slaanesh. The army of Elven souls she was attempting to build is somewhat diminished of late, as the Dark Prince claims many of the choicest specimens for himself.

short_description.last_approved_text: In her dark and gloomy kingdom, Ereth Khial plots new ways to reclaim the souls of the dead from Slaanesh.

technologies.short_description: In her dark and gloomy kingdom, Ereth Khial plots new ways to reclaim the souls of the dead from Slaanesh.

long_description.last_approved_text: Estreath is one of the few Ellinilli to have survived the wrath of their father. When word reached him that Ellinill had been tricked by Loec and intended to devour his children, Estreath fled to the mortal world. There he remains to this day, refusing to return to the heavens for fear of his father's retribution.

technologies.long_description: Estreath is one of the few Ellinilli to have survived the wrath of their father. When word reached him that Ellinill had been tricked by Loec and intended to devour his children, Estreath fled to the mortal world. There he remains to this day, refusing to return to the heavens for fear of his father's retribution.

short_description.last_approved_text: The Elves of Athel Loren know that each deity has a time and place.

technologies.short_description: The Elves of Athel Loren know that each deity has a time and place.

long_description.last_approved_text: Hekarti is a goddess of magic, but unlike Lileath she represents its darker side. A capricious deity, she pays close attention to the Elves' wants and desires, whereas other gods chose to avoid contact with them. As a result, she often finds herself in direct competition with her sister Atharti, the Goddess of Desire.

technologies.long_description: Hekarti is a goddess of magic, but unlike Lileath she represents its darker side. A capricious deity, she pays close attention to the Elves' wants and desires, whereas other gods chose to avoid contact with them. As a result, she often finds herself in direct competition with her sister Atharti, the Goddess of Desire.

short_description.last_approved_text: The Dark Mistress of Magic, Hekarti, draws those who worship her to the darker side of magic.

technologies.short_description: The Dark Mistress of Magic, Hekarti, draws those who worship her to the darker side of magic.

long_description.last_approved_text: The Sunderer is the Elven God of Earthquakes and one of the five Ellinilli to survive the wrath of his father by fleeing to the mortal world. Like all good fathers, Ellinill held a deep-seated distrust for his children. Although their power emanated from him, Ellinill worried that should they unite they would have the power to overthrow him. It was this distrust that Loec used to put an end to the Ellinilli's reign of terror.

technologies.long_description: The Sunderer is the Elven God of Earthquakes and one of the five Ellinilli to survive the wrath of his father by fleeing to the mortal world. Like all good fathers, Ellinill held a deep-seated distrust for his children. Although their power emanated from him, Ellinill worried that should they unite they would have the power to overthrow him. It was this distrust that Loec used to put an end to the Ellinilli's reign of terror.

short_description.last_approved_text: Hukon is the Elven God of Earthquakes and one of the few surviving members of the Ellinilli.

technologies.short_description: Hukon is the Elven God of Earthquakes and one of the few surviving members of the Ellinilli.

long_description.last_approved_text: Khaine is the Bloody-handed God of Murder. Where the High Elves keep their worship of him to a level that maintains his favour without completely surrendering themselves to him, the Dark Elves give body, mind and soul to Khaine. Wood Elves however, choose their deity according to their own natures. All Wood Elves hold Kurnous and Isha above all others, but are just as happy to embrace the wildness of Khaine as they are to embody the compassion of Lileath.

technologies.long_description: Khaine is the Bloody-handed God of Murder. Where the High Elves keep their worship of him to a level that maintains his favour without completely surrendering themselves to him, the Dark Elves give body, mind and soul to Khaine. Wood Elves however, choose their deity according to their own natures. All Wood Elves hold Kurnous and Isha above all others, but are just as happy to embrace the wildness of Khaine as they are to embody the compassion of Lileath.

short_description.last_approved_text: The Asrai worship where they will, choosing to honour the gods that best fit their personalities.

technologies.short_description: The Asrai worship where they will, choosing to honour the gods that best fit their personalities.

long_description.last_approved_text: As Lord of the Deeps, Mathlann is venerated by sailors and those that travel the deep blue sea. However, he is an uncaring deity, just as likely to curse his followers as he is to grant them safe passage. He is also known as King of Storm and Sea and has been known to send many a loyal Elf to their death. Worship at your peril!

technologies.long_description: As Lord of the Deeps, Mathlann is venerated by sailors and those that travel the deep blue sea. However, he is an uncaring deity, just as likely to curse his followers as he is to grant them safe passage. He is also known as King of Storm and Sea and has been known to send many a loyal Elf to their death. Worship at your peril!

short_description.last_approved_text: The capricious God of the Ocean is less than loyal to his followers.

technologies.short_description: The capricious God of the Ocean is less than loyal to his followers.

long_description.last_approved_text: As Lord of the Deeps, Mathlann is venerated by sailors and those that travel the deep blue sea. However, he is an uncaring deity, just as likely to curse his followers as he is to grant them safe passage. He is also known as King of Storm and Sea and has been known to send many a loyal Elf to their death. Worship at your peril!

technologies.long_description: As Lord of the Deeps, Mathlann is venerated by sailors and those that travel the deep blue sea. However, he is an uncaring deity, just as likely to curse his followers as he is to grant them safe passage. He is also known as King of Storm and Sea and has been known to send many a loyal Elf to their death. Worship at your peril!

short_description.last_approved_text: The capricious God of the Ocean is less than loyal to his followers.

technologies.short_description: The capricious God of the Ocean is less than loyal to his followers.

long_description.last_approved_text: Morai Heg is the Weaver of Prophecy and Keeper of Souls - she knows and sees everything and is responsible for laying out the secrets of the future in the stars. Each and every Elven death is foretold by her. The archers of Athel Loren have a deep respect for Morai Heg; no Elven archer would shoot down a raven as they are her chosen messengers.

technologies.long_description: Morai Heg is the Weaver of Prophecy and Keeper of Souls - she knows and sees everything and is responsible for laying out the secrets of the future in the stars. Each and every Elven death is foretold by her. The archers of Athel Loren have a deep respect for Morai Heg; no Elven archer would shoot down a raven as they are her chosen messengers.

short_description.last_approved_text: Also known as the Crone, Morai Heg is the only god in the Elven pantheon who is neither Cadai or Cytharai.

technologies.short_description: Also known as the Crone, Morai Heg is the only god in the Elven pantheon who is neither Cadai or Cytharai.

long_description.last_approved_text: Nethu is the gatekeeper of the Underworld and son to Ereth Khial. He is tasked with ensuring that the few souls claimed by his mother before they could be devoured by Slaanesh remain trapped until Rhana Dhandra, and that no living soul breaks into the realm of the dead to steal its secrets.

technologies.long_description: Nethu is the gatekeeper of the Underworld and son to Ereth Khial. He is tasked with ensuring that the few souls claimed by his mother before they could be devoured by Slaanesh remain trapped until Rhana Dhandra, and that no living soul breaks into the realm of the dead to steal its secrets.

onscreen_name.last_approved_text: Nethu, Keeper of the Last Door

technologies.onscreen_name: Nethu, Keeper of the Last Door

short_description.last_approved_text: The secrets of the Underworld are forbidden to those of the mortal realm. Nethu guards the pathways between them.

technologies.short_description: The secrets of the Underworld are forbidden to those of the mortal realm. Nethu guards the pathways between them.

long_description.last_approved_text: These shadowy spirits prey upon the souls of the Tree Kin. Only the most powerful of Elven souls become Tree Kin, so they are prized above all others. The Rephallim were once caged within the Wildwood, contained by the waystone markers that keep so many dark and vengeful spirits trapped. However, they were released by Ereth Khial, the Supreme Goddess of the Underworld, as she sought to reclaim some of the souls lost to the Chaos God Slaanesh.

technologies.long_description: These shadowy spirits prey upon the souls of the Tree Kin. Only the most powerful of Elven souls become Tree Kin, so they are prized above all others. The Rephallim were once caged within the Wildwood, contained by the waystone markers that keep so many dark and vengeful spirits trapped. However, they were released by Ereth Khial, the Supreme Goddess of the Underworld, as she sought to reclaim some of the souls lost to the Chaos God Slaanesh.

short_description.last_approved_text: Dark spirits of the Deepwood, they take the Tree Kin's very souls.

technologies.short_description: Dark spirits of the Deepwood, they take the Tree Kin's very souls.

long_description.last_approved_text: As the sacred woodland of Athel Loren is outside Bretonnia’s official boundaries, there are no Wood Elves living within its forests. Unfortunately, this means that Beastmen, the hideous Children of Chaos, infest the glades and copses with their fell rituals and darker appetites. Ever since the Great Battles of Bretonnian history, when the dreaded brayherds swept across the land in a stampede of destruction, joining with the foul, rampaging Greenskins to compound the misery of the local people. Some say that they may even exist in far greater numbers than previously thought, but no one is really prepared to venture into the woods to find out!

technologies.long_description: As the sacred woodland of Athel Loren is outside Bretonnia’s official boundaries, there are no Wood Elves living within its forests. Unfortunately, this means that Beastmen, the hideous Children of Chaos, infest the glades and copses with their fell rituals and darker appetites. Ever since the Great Battles of Bretonnian history, when the dreaded brayherds swept across the land in a stampede of destruction, joining with the foul, rampaging Greenskins to compound the misery of the local people. Some say that they may even exist in far greater numbers than previously thought, but no one is really prepared to venture into the woods to find out!

short_description.last_approved_text: “The king decrees that from this day forth, the forests of Bretonnia be made safe from the Beastmen’s Ruinous bane.”

technologies.short_description: “The king decrees that from this day forth, the forests of Bretonnia be made safe from the Beastmen’s Ruinous bane.”

long_description.last_approved_text: In Bretonnia from time to time, and with increasing regularity as the forces of Chaos strengthen their nefarious hold on the mortal world, formerly loyal and courageous dukes are tempted by promises of power and favour from the Ruinous Powers. No one, not even the brave and true Grail Knights, is immune from the outstretched tentacles of eternal madness to which such dark pacts give purchase. Yet the Lady of the Lake, through her servants the Fay Enchantress and courageous King Louen Leoncoeur, is ever-vigilant – ready to act in defence of Bretonnia wherever and whenever the Chaos Gods’ creeping, insidious influence is detected.

technologies.long_description: In Bretonnia from time to time, and with increasing regularity as the forces of Chaos strengthen their nefarious hold on the mortal world, formerly loyal and courageous dukes are tempted by promises of power and favour from the Ruinous Powers. No one, not even the brave and true Grail Knights, is immune from the outstretched tentacles of eternal madness to which such dark pacts give purchase. Yet the Lady of the Lake, through her servants the Fay Enchantress and courageous King Louen Leoncoeur, is ever-vigilant – ready to act in defence of Bretonnia wherever and whenever the Chaos Gods’ creeping, insidious influence is detected.

short_description.last_approved_text: "The king decrees that the scourge of Chaos be stopped at all costs and the land delivered to safety."

technologies.short_description: "The king decrees that the scourge of Chaos be stopped at all costs and the land delivered to safety."

short_description.last_approved_text: "The king decrees that the shores be secured against the vile raiders from Naggarond."

technologies.short_description: "The king decrees that the shores be secured against the vile raiders from Naggarond."

long_description.last_approved_text: Greenskins are central to the Bretonnian story, having been defeated by the Grail Companions in large numbers during the Great Battles. However, many years have passed since they have dared to raid in large groups away from their mountain strongholds, and some now fear they are gathering strength to move against Bretonnia once again. Attacks on border villages by small Warbands are not uncommon these days, with the farming and mining communities on the fringes especially vulnerable in Winter when cut off from the rest of Bretonnia. When the snow melts in Spring, at least one village has been reduced to rubble, its population dead or missing, and the stench of dung piles – the calling card of these foul, green interlopers – thick in the air.

technologies.long_description: Greenskins are central to the Bretonnian story, having been defeated by the Grail Companions in large numbers during the Great Battles. However, many years have passed since they have dared to raid in large groups away from their mountain strongholds, and some now fear they are gathering strength to move against Bretonnia once again. Attacks on border villages by small Warbands are not uncommon these days, with the farming and mining communities on the fringes especially vulnerable in Winter when cut off from the rest of Bretonnia. When the snow melts in Spring, at least one village has been reduced to rubble, its population dead or missing, and the stench of dung piles – the calling card of these foul, green interlopers – thick in the air.

short_description.last_approved_text: “The king decrees that the Greenskin blight be utterly annihilated wherever, whenever, and however possible!"

technologies.short_description: “The king decrees that the Greenskin blight be utterly annihilated wherever, whenever, and however possible!"

long_description.last_approved_text: Greenskins are central to the Bretonnian story, having been defeated by the Grail Companions in large numbers during the Great Battles. However, many years have passed since they have dared to raid in large groups away from their mountain strongholds, and some now fear they are gathering strength to move against Bretonnia once again. Attacks on border villages by small Warbands are not uncommon these days, with the farming and mining communities on the fringes especially vulnerable in Winter when cut off from the rest of Bretonnia. When the snow melts in Spring, at least one village has been reduced to rubble, its population dead or missing, and the stench of dung piles – the calling card of these foul, green interlopers – thick in the air.

technologies.long_description: Greenskins are central to the Bretonnian story, having been defeated by the Grail Companions in large numbers during the Great Battles. However, many years have passed since they have dared to raid in large groups away from their mountain strongholds, and some now fear they are gathering strength to move against Bretonnia once again. Attacks on border villages by small Warbands are not uncommon these days, with the farming and mining communities on the fringes especially vulnerable in Winter when cut off from the rest of Bretonnia. When the snow melts in Spring, at least one village has been reduced to rubble, its population dead or missing, and the stench of dung piles – the calling card of these foul, green interlopers – thick in the air.

short_description.last_approved_text: Too long have the Greenskins pillaged Bretonnian lands.

technologies.short_description: Too long have the Greenskins pillaged Bretonnian lands.

long_description.last_approved_text: The Northmen – the barbarian tribes allied to the Gods of Chaos – are ancient enemies of Bretonnia. During the Tenth Great Battle, Gilles le Breton and his Grail Companions came to the relief of the great port-city of L’Anguille, which was under attack from forces led by the formidable warrior-Lord Svengar of the Skaelings. The Companion Lord Marcus duelled with the giant Norscan warrior, defeating him and triggering a full-scale retreat of the Norse attackers, who hurriedly turned their ships around and sailed away northwards once more. A devastating victory was won that day, but nevertheless the ports of Bretonnia cast their eyes out to the ocean in constant vigilance even now.

technologies.long_description: The Northmen – the barbarian tribes allied to the Gods of Chaos – are ancient enemies of Bretonnia. During the Tenth Great Battle, Gilles le Breton and his Grail Companions came to the relief of the great port-city of L’Anguille, which was under attack from forces led by the formidable warrior-Lord Svengar of the Skaelings. The Companion Lord Marcus duelled with the giant Norscan warrior, defeating him and triggering a full-scale retreat of the Norse attackers, who hurriedly turned their ships around and sailed away northwards once more. A devastating victory was won that day, but nevertheless the ports of Bretonnia cast their eyes out to the ocean in constant vigilance even now.

short_description.last_approved_text: “The king decrees that Bretonnians must double their efforts to defend the Kingdom against the barbaric forces of the North.”

technologies.short_description: “The king decrees that Bretonnians must double their efforts to defend the Kingdom against the barbaric forces of the North.”

A devastating victory was won that day, but nevertheless the ports of Bretonnia cast their eyes out to the ocean in constant vigilance even now.

The Companion Lord Marcus duelled with the giant Norscan warrior, defeating him and triggering a full-scale retreat of the Norse attackers, who hurriedly turned their ships around and sailed away northwards once more. short_description.last_approved_text: Across the Sea of Claws lies an ancient threat; pay it the utmost attention, lest it grows too near.

technologies.short_description: Across the Sea of Claws lies an ancient threat; pay it the utmost attention, lest it grows too near.

short_description.last_approved_text: "The king decrees that the sewers should not provide refuge to abominations."

technologies.short_description: "The king decrees that the sewers should not provide refuge to abominations."

short_description.last_approved_text: "The king decrees that the trade routes will suffer no more harassment from desert bone-crawlers."

technologies.short_description: "The king decrees that the trade routes will suffer no more harassment from desert bone-crawlers."

long_description.last_approved_text: Being a superstitious lot, Bretonnians are not ones to take the threat of incursions by the Undead lightly. The idea of the dead walking is particularly abhorrent to them and a constant source of fear. Their history, especially that of the Great Battles, contains several tales of the Companions facing off against Necromancers and their reanimated hordes. More recently, Bretonnia seems to suffer more frequently from unnatural things defying nature and rising from their tombs at the bidding of Dark Magicians and Vampire Counts. This is especially true upriver from the cursed land of Mousillon, where waterlogged Undead crawl their way upstream, occasionally jumping out of the water and attacking unlucky passers-by!

technologies.long_description: Being a superstitious lot, Bretonnians are not ones to take the threat of incursions by the Undead lightly. The idea of the dead walking is particularly abhorrent to them and a constant source of fear. Their history, especially that of the Great Battles, contains several tales of the Companions facing off against Necromancers and their reanimated hordes. More recently, Bretonnia seems to suffer more frequently from unnatural things defying nature and rising from their tombs at the bidding of Dark Magicians and Vampire Counts. This is especially true upriver from the cursed land of Mousillon, where waterlogged Undead crawl their way upstream, occasionally jumping out of the water and attacking unlucky passers-by!

short_description.last_approved_text: "The king decrees that the threat of Unliving incursions be foremost in the collective mind of the kingdom."

technologies.short_description: "The king decrees that the threat of Unliving incursions be foremost in the collective mind of the kingdom."

long_description.last_approved_text: It is never wise to go against the Fey Folk of the forest, for they have long memories and their vengeance – for even the most trivial of slights – is total. In times past, men have exploited the forests, harvesting the trees for their selfish ends and have felt the Wood Elves’ wrath in return. As a result, the Bretonnians mostly stay away from Elven lands these days, so as not to tempt fate. For their part, the Elves do not consider the lives of ‘mayflies’ to be worth their time, so generally keep themselves to themselves where possible. There have, however, been instances of co-operation between the two races – for the good of the trees, of course. The Fourth Great Battle saw a horde of filthy, ravening Greenskins putting the forest to the flame and so the noble, courageous Grail Companions came to their aid, stopping the disgusting green tide dead in its tracks.

technologies.long_description: It is never wise to go against the Fey Folk of the forest, for they have long memories and their vengeance – for even the most trivial of slights – is total. In times past, men have exploited the forests, harvesting the trees for their selfish ends and have felt the Wood Elves’ wrath in return. As a result, the Bretonnians mostly stay away from Elven lands these days, so as not to tempt fate. For their part, the Elves do not consider the lives of ‘mayflies’ to be worth their time, so generally keep themselves to themselves where possible. There have, however, been instances of co-operation between the two races – for the good of the trees, of course. The Fourth Great Battle saw a horde of filthy, ravening Greenskins putting the forest to the flame and so the noble, courageous Grail Companions came to their aid, stopping the disgusting green tide dead in its tracks.

short_description.last_approved_text: "The king decrees that the malevolent forces of Athel Loren must be kept at bay."

technologies.short_description: "The king decrees that the malevolent forces of Athel Loren must be kept at bay."

long_description.last_approved_text: The tools and agricultural techniques used by Bretonnian peasants are considered by many to be rather backwards compared to those used by the other nations of men. Occasionally, cost-effective solutions developed by their counterparts in the Empire are adopted, while others less so. The main problem is that good tools are hard to find in Bretonnia and hence, are much more expensive. This means that less affluent Bretonnian nobles will not often see good reason to provide their peasant workers with better equipment if it can be avoided - to them, there is simply no reason to make a peasant’s job easier at a greater cost to themselves.

technologies.long_description: The tools and agricultural techniques used by Bretonnian peasants are considered by many to be rather backwards compared to those used by the other nations of men. Occasionally, cost-effective solutions developed by their counterparts in the Empire are adopted, while others less so. The main problem is that good tools are hard to find in Bretonnia and hence, are much more expensive. This means that less affluent Bretonnian nobles will not often see good reason to provide their peasant workers with better equipment if it can be avoided - to them, there is simply no reason to make a peasant’s job easier at a greater cost to themselves.

short_description.last_approved_text: No longer can a bad workman blame his tools…

technologies.short_description: No longer can a bad workman blame his tools…

long_description.last_approved_text: Ploughs are important to any agriculturally-focused economy, such as Bretonnia. Along with the pitchfork, they are a staple tool of the peasants who toil the fields, making the work slightly less back-breaking than would otherwise be the case, but not enough to make their miserable lives easier by any real degree. Increasing plough sizes does mean they spend less hours actually ploughing, freeing them up to do some other form of crippling manual labour for their noble masters.

technologies.long_description: Ploughs are important to any agriculturally-focused economy, such as Bretonnia. Along with the pitchfork, they are a staple tool of the peasants who toil the fields, making the work slightly less back-breaking than would otherwise be the case, but not enough to make their miserable lives easier by any real degree. Increasing plough sizes does mean they spend less hours actually ploughing, freeing them up to do some other form of crippling manual labour for their noble masters.

short_description.last_approved_text: The wider the plough, the higher the yield, in less time.

technologies.short_description: The wider the plough, the higher the yield, in less time.

long_description.last_approved_text: The ability of the Knightly class to effectively defend Bretonnia from harm rests with the peasants, who work the land to provide their nobles with the sustenance needed to fight wars in their name. The sheer amount of arable land in the region means that the waterways feeding the crops must work efficiently, lest the yields produced not be high enough. By the digging irrigation ditches, water can be directed to man-made watering holes around the foothills, where the pastoral farmers graze their animals, and to the rolling fields where maize and other crops are grown for their masters’ tables. The peasants themselves, however, rarely benefit from the abundance of high quality meat and fresh vegetables produced, and must content themselves with the gruel and scraps that are the lot of their pathetic, near-worthless lives.

technologies.long_description: The ability of the Knightly class to effectively defend Bretonnia from harm rests with the peasants, who work the land to provide their nobles with the sustenance needed to fight wars in their name. The sheer amount of arable land in the region means that the waterways feeding the crops must work efficiently, lest the yields produced not be high enough. By the digging irrigation ditches, water can be directed to man-made watering holes around the foothills, where the pastoral farmers graze their animals, and to the rolling fields where maize and other crops are grown for their masters’ tables. The peasants themselves, however, rarely benefit from the abundance of high quality meat and fresh vegetables produced, and must content themselves with the gruel and scraps that are the lot of their pathetic, near-worthless lives.

short_description.last_approved_text: Irrigation ensures that the fields are watered and the people fed, no matter the season.

technologies.short_description: Irrigation ensures that the fields are watered and the people fed, no matter the season.

long_description.last_approved_text: Although water pumping technology could be used to bring fresh water to the Bretonnian peasants, instead of the stagnant well water they are forced to drink, that is not considered important by the nobles whose land they work. As far as they are concerned, increasing produce yields is far more important than the needs of their workers, and so they are forbidden from using them for their own purposes. When more crops are grown than are needed to sustain the population, the excess can be used to trade with merchants for those essential luxuries – wine, for instance. Any other considerations, such as the welfare of the peasant population, are irrelevant.

technologies.long_description: Although water pumping technology could be used to bring fresh water to the Bretonnian peasants, instead of the stagnant well water they are forced to drink, that is not considered important by the nobles whose land they work. As far as they are concerned, increasing produce yields is far more important than the needs of their workers, and so they are forbidden from using them for their own purposes. When more crops are grown than are needed to sustain the population, the excess can be used to trade with merchants for those essential luxuries – wine, for instance. Any other considerations, such as the welfare of the peasant population, are irrelevant.

short_description.last_approved_text: The less we depend on the elements, the greater our control over our food supplies.

technologies.short_description: The less we depend on the elements, the greater our control over our food supplies.

short_description.last_approved_text: Steeds shod by a trained farrier have better purchase upon the roads and blessed ground of fair Bretonnia.

technologies.short_description: Steeds shod by a trained farrier have better purchase upon the roads and blessed ground of fair Bretonnia.

short_description.last_approved_text: The horses of Bretonnia are treated better than the smallfolk. Hay stores, for example, allow horses to feed all year round.

technologies.short_description: The horses of Bretonnia are treated better than the smallfolk. Hay stores, for example, allow horses to feed all year round.

short_description.last_approved_text: Blinker hoods restrict the eyesight of horses, making the beasts easier to control.

technologies.short_description: Blinker hoods restrict the eyesight of horses, making the beasts easier to control.

long_description.last_approved_text: Weaving cloth by hand is no easy task, as any clothiers will tell you. Unlike their neighbours in the technologically-burgeoning Empire, Bretonnians must do without the new-fangled machinery that saves labour and increases production. Such things might give the peasantry ideas, and are therefore eschewed by the kingdom’s noble, ruling class. Large-scale fabric production is a necessary evil, however, and so the work must be undertaken by hand or with the simplest, hand-driven looms. One effective way of keeping output high enough to meet demand is to increase the size of the spools used; anything further advanced might just trigger an industrial revolution – something no Bretonnian ruler wants to see!

technologies.long_description: Weaving cloth by hand is no easy task, as any clothiers will tell you. Unlike their neighbours in the technologically-burgeoning Empire, Bretonnians must do without the new-fangled machinery that saves labour and increases production. Such things might give the peasantry ideas, and are therefore eschewed by the kingdom’s noble, ruling class. Large-scale fabric production is a necessary evil, however, and so the work must be undertaken by hand or with the simplest, hand-driven looms. One effective way of keeping output high enough to meet demand is to increase the size of the spools used; anything further advanced might just trigger an industrial revolution – something no Bretonnian ruler wants to see!

short_description.last_approved_text: Bigger bobbins are better bobbins. It is known.

technologies.short_description: Bigger bobbins are better bobbins. It is known.

long_description.last_approved_text: Although the majority of Bretonnian weavers use simple wooden hand-looms, the pressures of increased production quotas have caused many breakages and repairs. Although loathed to do so, nobles have taken advantage of the importation of raw materials into Bretonnia – metals from Dwarf traders, for instance – to reinforce existing equipment or build new, more robust machinery from metal that will not break so easily.

technologies.long_description: Although the majority of Bretonnian weavers use simple wooden hand-looms, the pressures of increased production quotas have caused many breakages and repairs. Although loathed to do so, nobles have taken advantage of the importation of raw materials into Bretonnia – metals from Dwarf traders, for instance – to reinforce existing equipment or build new, more robust machinery from metal that will not break so easily.

short_description.last_approved_text: The fruit of such a loom is industry in abundance.

technologies.short_description: The fruit of such a loom is industry in abundance.

long_description.last_approved_text: In Bretonnia, the life of anyone outside the ruling class is tough. In keeping with natural order, the nobles take the vast majority of goods produced – and the profits therein – from the peasants who live on their land and do all the physical work. Although their skills are never recognised, weavers and other cloth workers are essential to Bretonnian industry, as the fruits of their labour directly bring income into the kingdom via trade with the travelling merchants that constantly move through the land. Naturally, the nobles do not approve of any activities that take peasants away from their toil, but even they have to admit that passing on knowledge to the next generation is useful – so there is someone to take over when a peasant craftsman eventually drops, exhausted, for the final time.

technologies.long_description: In Bretonnia, the life of anyone outside the ruling class is tough. In keeping with natural order, the nobles take the vast majority of goods produced – and the profits therein – from the peasants who live on their land and do all the physical work. Although their skills are never recognised, weavers and other cloth workers are essential to Bretonnian industry, as the fruits of their labour directly bring income into the kingdom via trade with the travelling merchants that constantly move through the land. Naturally, the nobles do not approve of any activities that take peasants away from their toil, but even they have to admit that passing on knowledge to the next generation is useful – so there is someone to take over when a peasant craftsman eventually drops, exhausted, for the final time.

short_description.last_approved_text: Time spent schooling the workers pays dividends later.

technologies.short_description: Time spent schooling the workers pays dividends later.

long_description.last_approved_text: Clothiers and seamstresses play an important role in Bretonnia, operating in a society which cares much about its image. For Bretonnians, chivalric virtues are not only expounded through their actions, but also through their appearance. Knights will often wear battle-damaged cloaks as a constant reminder of past glories, and some non-combatant nobles mimic this trend by having slits artificially cut into their own. Unsurprisingly, attempts to fake battle damage are frowned upon – so seamstresses are employed to adorn such cloaks with fabrics provided by the local clothier, making it clear that the battle damage is decorative.

technologies.long_description: Clothiers and seamstresses play an important role in Bretonnia, operating in a society which cares much about its image. For Bretonnians, chivalric virtues are not only expounded through their actions, but also through their appearance. Knights will often wear battle-damaged cloaks as a constant reminder of past glories, and some non-combatant nobles mimic this trend by having slits artificially cut into their own. Unsurprisingly, attempts to fake battle damage are frowned upon – so seamstresses are employed to adorn such cloaks with fabrics provided by the local clothier, making it clear that the battle damage is decorative.

short_description.last_approved_text: For some, appearances are everything - regardless of the truth of the matter.

technologies.short_description: For some, appearances are everything - regardless of the truth of the matter.

short_description.last_approved_text: Stealing or copying techniques and forge designs from their Empire neighbours improves Bretonnian metalworking.

technologies.short_description: Stealing or copying techniques and forge designs from their Empire neighbours improves Bretonnian metalworking.

short_description.last_approved_text: Building on breakthroughs in forge-design, kilns that can reach higher temperatures produce better earthenware.

technologies.short_description: Building on breakthroughs in forge-design, kilns that can reach higher temperatures produce better earthenware.

long_description.last_approved_text: As prolific builders of castles, improved stone masonry techniques and construction methods appeal to even the aggressively-feudalist Bretonnians. Unlike other areas of technological advancement, Bretonnian nobles are very keen on anything that speeds the process of building and maintaining the castles and strongholds from which their lands are defended from invaders. As a result, many improved construction methods have come along quickly and naturally out of necessity. It is important to remember, however, that the nobles’ preferred solution – in any situation – is always to throw more peasants at a problem until it goes away!

technologies.long_description: As prolific builders of castles, improved stone masonry techniques and construction methods appeal to even the aggressively-feudalist Bretonnians. Unlike other areas of technological advancement, Bretonnian nobles are very keen on anything that speeds the process of building and maintaining the castles and strongholds from which their lands are defended from invaders. As a result, many improved construction methods have come along quickly and naturally out of necessity. It is important to remember, however, that the nobles’ preferred solution – in any situation – is always to throw more peasants at a problem until it goes away!

short_description.last_approved_text: Improve the process and the results look after themselves.

technologies.short_description: Improve the process and the results look after themselves.

short_description.last_approved_text: The designs of these mighty furnaces have been taken from Nuln, and are used to create hardened plate.

technologies.short_description: The designs of these mighty furnaces have been taken from Nuln, and are used to create hardened plate.

short_description.last_approved_text: Folding steel takes great skill; the more folds, the stronger and sharper the blade.

technologies.short_description: Folding steel takes great skill; the more folds, the stronger and sharper the blade.

short_description.last_approved_text: Tournaments are a way for noble knights to gain honour and maintain martial skills during rare glimpses of peacetime.

technologies.short_description: Tournaments are a way for noble knights to gain honour and maintain martial skills during rare glimpses of peacetime.

long_description.last_approved_text: Almshouses in Bretonnia are not happy places, but serve an important function for the peasant-class, who endlessly toil for the nobility in exchange for their ‘protection’ from evil in its various guises. Naturally, peasants only know servitude, leaving the Knights to carry out the heroic deeds so revered in Bretonnian society. Such loyalty is not reciprocated, however, for if peasants become afflicted by disease or injury to the extent that they can no longer toil the fields or work the looms, they are simply replaced by others in better physical condition. Almshouses provide a modicum of refuge to those wretched individuals who find themselves in such unfortunate predicaments. Such places are not a soft-option though – residents lives remaining hard, they are still expected to work long hours at menial tasks, with barely enough food provided and absolutely no sympathy, cures or palliative care offered.

technologies.long_description: Almshouses in Bretonnia are not happy places, but serve an important function for the peasant-class, who endlessly toil for the nobility in exchange for their ‘protection’ from evil in its various guises. Naturally, peasants only know servitude, leaving the Knights to carry out the heroic deeds so revered in Bretonnian society. Such loyalty is not reciprocated, however, for if peasants become afflicted by disease or injury to the extent that they can no longer toil the fields or work the looms, they are simply replaced by others in better physical condition. Almshouses provide a modicum of refuge to those wretched individuals who find themselves in such unfortunate predicaments. Such places are not a soft-option though – residents lives remaining hard, they are still expected to work long hours at menial tasks, with barely enough food provided and absolutely no sympathy, cures or palliative care offered.

short_description.last_approved_text: The poor must be cared for, just enough to ensure productivity.

technologies.short_description: The poor must be cared for, just enough to ensure productivity.

long_description.last_approved_text: The structure of Bretonnian society is not concerned with the peasants – the vast, faceless rabble who do all the actual work, suffer and die without ever finding solace for their woes or redress for their concerns. For that reason, it’s very hard for a noble to truly know how many live and work his lands. Some landowners have thousands in order to work their sizeable estates, others just a few hundred to operate the looms which produce the cloth he trades in order to prop up his already-considerable wealth. It makes sense then, for each to survey his workers and send details of their numbers to the capital so the king knows how many can be levied to fight in his armies in the event of war.

technologies.long_description: The structure of Bretonnian society is not concerned with the peasants – the vast, faceless rabble who do all the actual work, suffer and die without ever finding solace for their woes or redress for their concerns. For that reason, it’s very hard for a noble to truly know how many live and work his lands. Some landowners have thousands in order to work their sizeable estates, others just a few hundred to operate the looms which produce the cloth he trades in order to prop up his already-considerable wealth. It makes sense then, for each to survey his workers and send details of their numbers to the capital so the king knows how many can be levied to fight in his armies in the event of war.

short_description.last_approved_text: Know your population, know the size of your army.

technologies.short_description: Know your population, know the size of your army.

long_description.last_approved_text: In the context of Bretonnia, it is misleading to think of the pitchfork as a symbol of peasant rebellion, since such uprisings are so rare within its dukedoms. The low-born are far more likely to use a pitchfork to defend their noble’s land than turn it against the noble himself. It also means that when war inevitably comes, he doesn’t have to spend valuable resources on weapons that he could otherwise spend on arming his Knights. Therefore, the high-born know that to give a Bretonnian peasant a pitchfork is to hand him a useful tool with which to work the fields and forearm him for the battles ahead.

technologies.long_description: In the context of Bretonnia, it is misleading to think of the pitchfork as a symbol of peasant rebellion, since such uprisings are so rare within its dukedoms. The low-born are far more likely to use a pitchfork to defend their noble’s land than turn it against the noble himself. It also means that when war inevitably comes, he doesn’t have to spend valuable resources on weapons that he could otherwise spend on arming his Knights. Therefore, the high-born know that to give a Bretonnian peasant a pitchfork is to hand him a useful tool with which to work the fields and forearm him for the battles ahead.

short_description.last_approved_text: For what is a peasant without his pitchfork?

technologies.short_description: For what is a peasant without his pitchfork?

long_description.last_approved_text: Naturally, in a feudal society such as Bretonnia, peasant handouts are extremely rare, so when they do occur, they have a profound effect. Knights typically never share their riches with the low-born, be it battle-loot or the profits of his peasants ceaseless labour. Bretonnian peasants are, to a man, pitifully-poor individuals, who serve their betters past the point of total exhaustion while paying taxes almost as high as their paltry wages. Even if they are fortunate enough to become Men-at-Arms and take to the battlefield alongside Knights of the Realm, they must still pay for their own rations and bring their own equipment.

technologies.long_description: Naturally, in a feudal society such as Bretonnia, peasant handouts are extremely rare, so when they do occur, they have a profound effect. Knights typically never share their riches with the low-born, be it battle-loot or the profits of his peasants ceaseless labour. Bretonnian peasants are, to a man, pitifully-poor individuals, who serve their betters past the point of total exhaustion while paying taxes almost as high as their paltry wages. Even if they are fortunate enough to become Men-at-Arms and take to the battlefield alongside Knights of the Realm, they must still pay for their own rations and bring their own equipment.

short_description.last_approved_text: “Rejoice, peasants! For a generous Knight of Bretonnia provides for you!”

technologies.short_description: “Rejoice, peasants! For a generous Knight of Bretonnia provides for you!”

short_description.last_approved_text: While wood is plentiful, carpentry skills remain relatively rare and so are prized in Bretonnia.

technologies.short_description: While wood is plentiful, carpentry skills remain relatively rare and so are prized in Bretonnia.

short_description.last_approved_text: Once the town census has been undertaken, its easy to round the peons up for military service.

technologies.short_description: Once the town census has been undertaken, its easy to round the peons up for military service.

short_description.last_approved_text: For those not born into nobility, there are few ways to gain the Lady's favour.

technologies.short_description: For those not born into nobility, there are few ways to gain the Lady's favour.

short_description.last_approved_text: Those peasants skilled at bow-making are ordered to do it year round, instead of supplying a village's quota.

technologies.short_description: Those peasants skilled at bow-making are ordered to do it year round, instead of supplying a village's quota.

short_description.last_approved_text: This requires educated men, often those who have studied abroad in the universities of Estalia or the Empire.

technologies.short_description: This requires educated men, often those who have studied abroad in the universities of Estalia or the Empire.

short_description.last_approved_text: Better woodworking techniques allow for longer, more sturdy spears and polearms.

technologies.short_description: Better woodworking techniques allow for longer, more sturdy spears and polearms.

short_description.last_approved_text: Paladins are expected to donate large sums of their inheritance to the cult of the Lady.

technologies.short_description: Paladins are expected to donate large sums of their inheritance to the cult of the Lady.

long_description.last_approved_text: Bretonnian society looks down on progress, for such things may lead to ‘undesirable’ changes to the balance of power. This makes for a haphazard economy which does not stockpile goods when it would perhaps be sensible to do so. Generally, trade is what keeps the kingdom going, with nobles dealing with the merchant class when necessary in order to obtain the goods they need and trading wine and textiles in return. Of course, the village communities who do all of the actual production work do not benefit from this – diffusion of wealth being an alien concept in such a staunchly feudal society. Those landowners whose local industries may be suffering simply drive their peasants harder until the profits made are high enough to keep them in the manner to which they are accustomed – as is their noble birthright of course.

technologies.long_description: Bretonnian society looks down on progress, for such things may lead to ‘undesirable’ changes to the balance of power. This makes for a haphazard economy which does not stockpile goods when it would perhaps be sensible to do so. Generally, trade is what keeps the kingdom going, with nobles dealing with the merchant class when necessary in order to obtain the goods they need and trading wine and textiles in return. Of course, the village communities who do all of the actual production work do not benefit from this – diffusion of wealth being an alien concept in such a staunchly feudal society. Those landowners whose local industries may be suffering simply drive their peasants harder until the profits made are high enough to keep them in the manner to which they are accustomed – as is their noble birthright of course.

short_description.last_approved_text: Banish uncertainty: invest in the kingdom's future.

technologies.short_description: Banish uncertainty: invest in the kingdom's future.

long_description.last_approved_text: The sea merchants who operate off Bretonnia’s shores constantly need tougher, more manoeuvrable ships. The rapidly changing currents off the coast, extreme gales that blow in from the Great Ocean to the west, pirates, and – not to forget – the sea-monsters who infest its waters are notoriously dangerous to navigate. Even the most experienced sailors find it difficult to avoid a shipwreck if they find themselves in an unfamiliar waters. These difficulties can sometimes hamper trade, since a lot of goods flowing in and out of Bretonnian ports use the congested, land-hugging ship-routes.

technologies.long_description: The sea merchants who operate off Bretonnia’s shores constantly need tougher, more manoeuvrable ships. The rapidly changing currents off the coast, extreme gales that blow in from the Great Ocean to the west, pirates, and – not to forget – the sea-monsters who infest its waters are notoriously dangerous to navigate. Even the most experienced sailors find it difficult to avoid a shipwreck if they find themselves in an unfamiliar waters. These difficulties can sometimes hamper trade, since a lot of goods flowing in and out of Bretonnian ports use the congested, land-hugging ship-routes.

short_description.last_approved_text: A seaworthy fleet keeps the economy afloat.

technologies.short_description: A seaworthy fleet keeps the economy afloat.

long_description.last_approved_text: Bretonnia wears a fair mask over the not-uncommon presence of corruption. The harbourmasters who control access to all its lucrative trade ports make a decent living, but not always entirely by honest means. Often, following receipt of certain payments, they are able to direct ‘approved’ smugglers to safe moorings around Bretonnia’s perilous coast in order to avoid the tolls and duties levied at its major ports – knowledge they are often more than willing to share for the right price.

technologies.long_description: Bretonnia wears a fair mask over the not-uncommon presence of corruption. The harbourmasters who control access to all its lucrative trade ports make a decent living, but not always entirely by honest means. Often, following receipt of certain payments, they are able to direct ‘approved’ smugglers to safe moorings around Bretonnia’s perilous coast in order to avoid the tolls and duties levied at its major ports – knowledge they are often more than willing to share for the right price.

short_description.last_approved_text: Bribing the harbourmaster pays dividends on import duties.

technologies.short_description: Bribing the harbourmaster pays dividends on import duties.

long_description.last_approved_text: The forested realm of Artois has notable significance in Bretonnia’s history – it was the location of the first Gathering of the Companions, where the fourteen newly-united dukedoms were first legitimised. Emblazoned on the Heraldry of Artois is the head of the monstrous boar Morthanok, symbol of Lord Folgar, the first Duke of Artois. A renowned hunter and lancer, Folgar's skills made him an invaluable Companion Knight who fought in several Great Battles alongside Gilles le Breton. Morthanok’s image is a reminder of the inaugural feast of the Companions, for which Folgar hunted down and slew the dangerous beast.

technologies.long_description: The forested realm of Artois has notable significance in Bretonnia’s history – it was the location of the first Gathering of the Companions, where the fourteen newly-united dukedoms were first legitimised. Emblazoned on the Heraldry of Artois is the head of the monstrous boar Morthanok, symbol of Lord Folgar, the first Duke of Artois. A renowned hunter and lancer, Folgar's skills made him an invaluable Companion Knight who fought in several Great Battles alongside Gilles le Breton. Morthanok’s image is a reminder of the inaugural feast of the Companions, for which Folgar hunted down and slew the dangerous beast.

short_description.last_approved_text: Artois, where the unified dukedoms swore fealty to the Uniter.

technologies.short_description: Artois, where the unified dukedoms swore fealty to the Uniter.

long_description.last_approved_text: Prior to the Lady appearing before the Uniter and his fellow Grail Knights, the young Gilles rode out to cleanse his homeland Bastonne of the foul beasts wreaking havoc there. After slaying one such beast – the ancient Dragon Smearghus – he not only adopted its image on his Heraldry, but also wore its skin as part of his armour during all his Great Battles. To this day, the beast’s image and its pelt are revered in Bastonne, with the armour still kept and worn by the duke ceremoniously as well as in warfare.

technologies.long_description: Prior to the Lady appearing before the Uniter and his fellow Grail Knights, the young Gilles rode out to cleanse his homeland Bastonne of the foul beasts wreaking havoc there. After slaying one such beast – the ancient Dragon Smearghus – he not only adopted its image on his Heraldry, but also wore its skin as part of his armour during all his Great Battles. To this day, the beast’s image and its pelt are revered in Bastonne, with the armour still kept and worn by the duke ceremoniously as well as in warfare.

short_description.last_approved_text: Bastonne, birthplace of the Uniter and the source of his bloodline.

technologies.short_description: Bastonne, birthplace of the Uniter and the source of his bloodline.

long_description.last_approved_text: Bordeleaux is a land peacefully split over religious matters. Those residing on the coastlines assert that the Lady’s domain ends where the water turns salt – where the domain of Manann begins. The tempestuous Sea God’s tri-forked symbol is a reminder of the bond he forged with the bloodline of the Bordelen dukes, during the Tenth Great Battle, against the sea-raiders from the North. Lord Marcus, the first Duke of Bordeleaux, was said to have fought alongside Manann himself that day, ending the battle by challenging and defeating the giant warrior in command of the Norscans that day.

technologies.long_description: Bordeleaux is a land peacefully split over religious matters. Those residing on the coastlines assert that the Lady’s domain ends where the water turns salt – where the domain of Manann begins. The tempestuous Sea God’s tri-forked symbol is a reminder of the bond he forged with the bloodline of the Bordelen dukes, during the Tenth Great Battle, against the sea-raiders from the North. Lord Marcus, the first Duke of Bordeleaux, was said to have fought alongside Manann himself that day, ending the battle by challenging and defeating the giant warrior in command of the Norscans that day.

short_description.last_approved_text: Manann is more than a mere deity; he is a source of livelihood for many Bordelen citizens.

technologies.short_description: Manann is more than a mere deity; he is a source of livelihood for many Bordelen citizens.

long_description.last_approved_text: King Leoncoeur's homeland of Couronne currently flies the heraldry of Bretonnia. The heritage of Couronne’s dukedom has ties to the original Grail Companions of Gilles the Uniter – their first duke was the heroic Carleond, saviour of the city and older brother of the most devoted Companion of them all, Thierulf of Lyonesse. As children, the two brothers were said to have miraculously slain a great lion together, which is why the heraldries of Lyonesse and Couronne – and hence, the heraldry of Bretonnia – display a lion’s image.

technologies.long_description: King Leoncoeur's homeland of Couronne currently flies the heraldry of Bretonnia. The heritage of Couronne’s dukedom has ties to the original Grail Companions of Gilles the Uniter – their first duke was the heroic Carleond, saviour of the city and older brother of the most devoted Companion of them all, Thierulf of Lyonesse. As children, the two brothers were said to have miraculously slain a great lion together, which is why the heraldries of Lyonesse and Couronne – and hence, the heraldry of Bretonnia – display a lion’s image.

short_description.last_approved_text: King Leoncoeur leads Bretonnia; his symbol, the Shield of Couronne.

technologies.short_description: King Leoncoeur leads Bretonnia; his symbol, the Shield of Couronne.

long_description.last_approved_text: It was Duke Lambard of Carcassonne, one of the famed Companions of Gilles the Uniter, who first adopted the image of the sword for his nation’s Heraldry. Although Carcassonne was one of few Bretonnian provinces that did not see a Great Battle on its lands, Lambard rode out to fight victoriously in nine of them. The blade symbolises Carcassonne’s warrior-culture, attested by their centuries-old tradition of gifting every newborn son a freshly-forged sword, which they are made to touch as soon as they enter the world. It is then ornamentally placed above their cots until it can be wielded.

technologies.long_description: It was Duke Lambard of Carcassonne, one of the famed Companions of Gilles the Uniter, who first adopted the image of the sword for his nation’s Heraldry. Although Carcassonne was one of few Bretonnian provinces that did not see a Great Battle on its lands, Lambard rode out to fight victoriously in nine of them. The blade symbolises Carcassonne’s warrior-culture, attested by their centuries-old tradition of gifting every newborn son a freshly-forged sword, which they are made to touch as soon as they enter the world. It is then ornamentally placed above their cots until it can be wielded.

short_description.last_approved_text: The sons of Carcassonne bear the symbol of the sword, the insignia of their warrior-culture.

technologies.short_description: The sons of Carcassonne bear the symbol of the sword, the insignia of their warrior-culture.

short_description.last_approved_text: The ongoing Errantry Wars across the sea need constant political and financial support.

technologies.short_description: The ongoing Errantry Wars across the sea need constant political and financial support.

long_description.last_approved_text: The Heraldry of Lyonesse was originally adopted by Thierulf, the most devoted of Gilles le Breton’s Grail Companions. In the years before the Great Battles, Thierulf of Lyonesse married Gilles’ sister and became his brother-in-law’s most trusted friend. He would later be one of the two Companions blessed by the Lady alongside Gilles himself, going on to fight victoriously in all twelve of the Great Battles with him. Lyonesse's Lion-symbol represents Thierhulf’s courageous nature in battle, and also the beast that he and his brother are said to have miraculously slain as children.

technologies.long_description: The Heraldry of Lyonesse was originally adopted by Thierulf, the most devoted of Gilles le Breton’s Grail Companions. In the years before the Great Battles, Thierulf of Lyonesse married Gilles’ sister and became his brother-in-law’s most trusted friend. He would later be one of the two Companions blessed by the Lady alongside Gilles himself, going on to fight victoriously in all twelve of the Great Battles with him. Lyonesse's Lion-symbol represents Thierhulf’s courageous nature in battle, and also the beast that he and his brother are said to have miraculously slain as children.

short_description.last_approved_text: Lyonesse, the homeland of the most devoted of all the Grail Companions.

technologies.short_description: Lyonesse, the homeland of the most devoted of all the Grail Companions.

short_description.last_approved_text: The king knows that it cannot be Bretonnia alone which stems the tide of filth - diplomats and envoys are required to broker alliances.

technologies.short_description: The king knows that it cannot be Bretonnia alone which stems the tide of filth - diplomats and envoys are required to broker alliances.

long_description.last_approved_text: Adorning the family standard of the dukes of Parravon is the pegasus rampant, the ultimate symbol of wealth for any Knight fortunate enough to acquire one. This Heraldry was adopted by Lord Agilgar, first Duke of Parravon and one of the famed Companions of Gilles the Uniter. It is said to be a likeness of his winged steed Glorfinial, lord and sire of all Royal pegasi, whom he befriended. It was atop his friend Glorfinial that Agilgar was carried into the Fifth Great Battle – the liberation of Parravon – paving his way to Companionhood by his actions that day.

technologies.long_description: Adorning the family standard of the dukes of Parravon is the pegasus rampant, the ultimate symbol of wealth for any Knight fortunate enough to acquire one. This Heraldry was adopted by Lord Agilgar, first Duke of Parravon and one of the famed Companions of Gilles the Uniter. It is said to be a likeness of his winged steed Glorfinial, lord and sire of all Royal pegasi, whom he befriended. It was atop his friend Glorfinial that Agilgar was carried into the Fifth Great Battle – the liberation of Parravon – paving his way to Companionhood by his actions that day.

short_description.last_approved_text: Among the cliffs, peaks, and mountain ranges, the pegasi soar.

technologies.short_description: Among the cliffs, peaks, and mountain ranges, the pegasi soar.

long_description.last_approved_text: Bretonnia is renowned as a land with a code of conduct that must be followed by all those with noble blood. The code is not just about a Knight’s behaviour – although that is also important – but also about the choices he makes during his exploits. Living for the moment, a Knight should always choose the most honourable course of action. To them, what matters is what they do now, not what they may or may not do in the future. It is often as simple as seeking battle as a way of securing personal honour and pride.

technologies.long_description: Bretonnia is renowned as a land with a code of conduct that must be followed by all those with noble blood. The code is not just about a Knight’s behaviour – although that is also important – but also about the choices he makes during his exploits. Living for the moment, a Knight should always choose the most honourable course of action. To them, what matters is what they do now, not what they may or may not do in the future. It is often as simple as seeking battle as a way of securing personal honour and pride.

short_description.last_approved_text: Every Bretonnian Lord knows that honour and chivalry come before everything.

technologies.short_description: Every Bretonnian Lord knows that honour and chivalry come before everything.

long_description.last_approved_text: When the fourteen standards of Bretonnia come together, it is one of the most majestic displays of unity in the Old World. Gilles le Breton could not have achieved the unification of the Kingdom without the divine Blessing of the Lady and the other Companions, the first dukes of Bretonnia. When the greatest Knights across the fourteen Dukedoms come together to fight as one, as they did on the day of the final Great Battle, it is truly a sight to behold. It is an inspiring show of solidarity, earning respect of both men and Dwarfs alike.

technologies.long_description: When the fourteen standards of Bretonnia come together, it is one of the most majestic displays of unity in the Old World. Gilles le Breton could not have achieved the unification of the Kingdom without the divine Blessing of the Lady and the other Companions, the first dukes of Bretonnia. When the greatest Knights across the fourteen Dukedoms come together to fight as one, as they did on the day of the final Great Battle, it is truly a sight to behold. It is an inspiring show of solidarity, earning respect of both men and Dwarfs alike.

short_description.last_approved_text: One people, one land – all shall know its glory and grandeur.

technologies.short_description: One people, one land – all shall know its glory and grandeur.

short_description.last_approved_text: Through the ancient Necrotect runes inscribed on your marching drums, the Unliving may be driven to march at a greater pace.

technologies.short_description: Through the ancient Necrotect runes inscribed on your marching drums, the Unliving may be driven to march at a greater pace.

short_description.last_approved_text: A First-Dynasty graveyard chant has been discovered, imbuing Skeleton Warriors with greater agility in battle.

technologies.short_description: A First-Dynasty graveyard chant has been discovered, imbuing Skeleton Warriors with greater agility in battle.

short_description.last_approved_text: Construction scrolls have been disinterred, making it possible to improve certain units’ weapons and armour.

technologies.short_description: Construction scrolls have been disinterred, making it possible to improve certain units’ weapons and armour.

short_description.last_approved_text: This ancient Nehekharan incantation is capable of raising hosts from ‘neath the sands, fully armed and charged with the foe’s destruction.

technologies.short_description: This ancient Nehekharan incantation is capable of raising hosts from ‘neath the sands, fully armed and charged with the foe’s destruction.

short_description.last_approved_text: Raising elite riders and their steeds from Second Dynasty nomadic battle sites bolsters your cavalry forces.

technologies.short_description: Raising elite riders and their steeds from Second Dynasty nomadic battle sites bolsters your cavalry forces.

short_description.last_approved_text: As posited by Rakaph III, bone makes both an effective weapon and surprisingly durable armour for Undead warriors.

technologies.short_description: As posited by Rakaph III, bone makes both an effective weapon and surprisingly durable armour for Undead warriors.

short_description.last_approved_text: A ritual supplication to the vulture-headed God of Scavengers shall ensure his spawn make reliable allies.

technologies.short_description: A ritual supplication to the vulture-headed God of Scavengers shall ensure his spawn make reliable allies.

short_description.last_approved_text: It is said that a drop of purest venom, placed upon the lips of the sacrificial victim, will rouse the Scorpion-God himself.

technologies.short_description: It is said that a drop of purest venom, placed upon the lips of the sacrificial victim, will rouse the Scorpion-God himself.

short_description.last_approved_text: Mortuary Cult devotees know all about the most fruitful burial grounds. Assigned to garrison, such knowledge is invaluable.

technologies.short_description: Mortuary Cult devotees know all about the most fruitful burial grounds. Assigned to garrison, such knowledge is invaluable.

short_description.last_approved_text: Though long dead, kingly guardians can be reminded of their oaths of service made in ages past, invigorating them for battle.

technologies.short_description: Though long dead, kingly guardians can be reminded of their oaths of service made in ages past, invigorating them for battle.

short_description.last_approved_text: If they can disregard their former rivalries and toil together in common cause, Necrotects can achieve engineering wonders.

technologies.short_description: If they can disregard their former rivalries and toil together in common cause, Necrotects can achieve engineering wonders.

short_description.last_approved_text: With minor adjustments to everyday incantations, the dead may be made to rise with greater vigour than they ever knew in life.

technologies.short_description: With minor adjustments to everyday incantations, the dead may be made to rise with greater vigour than they ever knew in life.

short_description.last_approved_text: Studying the splendid cartography of the Fifth Dynasty shows you exactly where to source veteran stock.

technologies.short_description: Studying the splendid cartography of the Fifth Dynasty shows you exactly where to source veteran stock.

short_description.last_approved_text: A burnt offering, combined with the correct ritual address, brings great dexterity to a Necropolis Knight's mount.

technologies.short_description: A burnt offering, combined with the correct ritual address, brings great dexterity to a Necropolis Knight's mount.

short_description.last_approved_text: Fifth Dynasty scrolls show the locations of Necroserpent nests, where the beasts sit coiled beneath the sands, on a bed of howling skulls.

technologies.short_description: Fifth Dynasty scrolls show the locations of Necroserpent nests, where the beasts sit coiled beneath the sands, on a bed of howling skulls.

short_description.last_approved_text: Trinkets and ritual masks bearing Ptra's sigil are bestowed upon your stone guardians, making them fight all the harder.

technologies.short_description: Trinkets and ritual masks bearing Ptra's sigil are bestowed upon your stone guardians, making them fight all the harder.

short_description.last_approved_text: Forbidden scrolls found in the deep desert reveal portals to Usirian’s realm. This is where the Necrosphinx lurk, awaiting to be tethered to a dread statue.

technologies.short_description: Forbidden scrolls found in the deep desert reveal portals to Usirian’s realm. This is where the Necrosphinx lurk, awaiting to be tethered to a dread statue.

short_description.last_approved_text: Huge Sixth Dynasty gold reserves have been recovered - perfect for ornamenting our most prestigious edifices.

technologies.short_description: Huge Sixth Dynasty gold reserves have been recovered - perfect for ornamenting our most prestigious edifices.

short_description.last_approved_text: Ruling from the glittering capital of Khemri, Settra bound the disparate Priest Kings into the unity of single kingdom and lo, Nehekhara was born.

technologies.short_description: Ruling from the glittering capital of Khemri, Settra bound the disparate Priest Kings into the unity of single kingdom and lo, Nehekhara was born.

short_description.last_approved_text: The Second dynasty marked a period of sweeping territorial expansion and growing prosperity for Nehekhara.

technologies.short_description: The Second dynasty marked a period of sweeping territorial expansion and growing prosperity for Nehekhara.

short_description.last_approved_text: The kingdom prospered further until Nagash's treacherous rise to power, although he was finally defeated by the united Priest Kings.

technologies.short_description: The kingdom prospered further until Nagash's treacherous rise to power, although he was finally defeated by the united Priest Kings.

short_description.last_approved_text: In the aftermath of Nagash's reign of terror, king succeeded king in a period of great strife, division and civil war.

technologies.short_description: In the aftermath of Nagash's reign of terror, king succeeded king in a period of great strife, division and civil war.

short_description.last_approved_text: King Setep usurped the throne of Khemri, restoring the Priesthood and the Necropolis; from then on, Nehekhara began to flourish once more.

technologies.short_description: King Setep usurped the throne of Khemri, restoring the Priesthood and the Necropolis; from then on, Nehekhara began to flourish once more.

short_description.last_approved_text: A resurgent Nehekhara reached its peak under Alcadizzar. Nagash returned, and after years of war, Nehekhara finally fell into decay.

technologies.short_description: A resurgent Nehekhara reached its peak under Alcadizzar. Nagash returned, and after years of war, Nehekhara finally fell into decay.

short_description.last_approved_text: Knowing precisely where to place the killing blow, Rasetra's Crocodile Squadron turned swordplay into an art form.

technologies.short_description: Knowing precisely where to place the killing blow, Rasetra's Crocodile Squadron turned swordplay into an art form.

short_description.last_approved_text: The Ushabti of Djaf's Messengers fought with legendary zeal, even as the odds against them grew.

technologies.short_description: The Ushabti of Djaf's Messengers fought with legendary zeal, even as the odds against them grew.

short_description.last_approved_text: With gilded bones and magically-honed blades, the Golden Host of Mahrak were the glory of the Third Dynasty.

technologies.short_description: With gilded bones and magically-honed blades, the Golden Host of Mahrak were the glory of the Third Dynasty.

short_description.last_approved_text: Beguiling and deceptive, the Sphinx Legion of Numas caught countless foes unprepared, even in the open field.

technologies.short_description: Beguiling and deceptive, the Sphinx Legion of Numas caught countless foes unprepared, even in the open field.

short_description.last_approved_text: With the Vulture-God Ualatp at their backs, the Zandri Blackshields drove their chariots with preternatural speed.

technologies.short_description: With the Vulture-God Ualatp at their backs, the Zandri Blackshields drove their chariots with preternatural speed.

short_description.last_approved_text: The arrows of the Hawk Legion of Khemri always found their mark at necks, groins and the tiniest chinks in enemy armour.

technologies.short_description: The arrows of the Hawk Legion of Khemri always found their mark at necks, groins and the tiniest chinks in enemy armour.

short_description.last_approved_text: Blessed by Sokth himself, the Scorpion Guard could shrug off mortal blows and carve through infantry with horrifying efficiency.

technologies.short_description: Blessed by Sokth himself, the Scorpion Guard could shrug off mortal blows and carve through infantry with horrifying efficiency.

short_description.last_approved_text: March, my legions - plant the seeds of civilisation upon the lands of Nehek!

technologies.short_description: March, my legions - plant the seeds of civilisation upon the lands of Nehek!

short_description.last_approved_text: From the sands come steed and shadow - the desert stables open to the gallop of death!

technologies.short_description: From the sands come steed and shadow - the desert stables open to the gallop of death!

short_description.last_approved_text: Make ready our cities - build upon strong foundations so they stand the test of time!

technologies.short_description: Make ready our cities - build upon strong foundations so they stand the test of time!

short_description.last_approved_text: Defend your kingdom and attack the weak. Glory is in victory at all costs.

technologies.short_description: Defend your kingdom and attack the weak. Glory is in victory at all costs.
